participants.participant: Pierre Gadonneix, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning everyone and welcome to this presentation of EDF's 2008 Financial Results. The year 2000 would have been far ago and brand new largely commented on it and you've seen it in the media. 2008 would have been a decisive milestone in the implementation of EDF's strategy both in France and internationally and it's a decisive milestone to structure and consolidate our industrial future. The two structuring acquisitions that we completed in 2008 lay the foundation for our future expansion in the nuclear revival. The acquisition of British Energy in the U.K. on the one hand and the Constellation acquisition in the U.S. on the other hand.

We've actually made the only choice that could guarantee our industrial future, namely to expand outside of our historical borders in France. Indeed, our leadership in the nuclear industry will take place internationally on those markets where the largest number of nuclear reactors will be built over the next decade. The recent announcement of the construction of the second EPR reactor in France fits perfectly within this new industrial strategy, namely the development of CO2-free energies in order to bolster our energy independence with a renewal and revival of nuclear power and the development of renewable energy sources. This is also the only way to sustain our expertise and know-how in order to prepare ultimately the full renewal of the French nuclear generation capacities. I am convinced that all of these prospects mark a decisive turning point in the history of EDF.

In the current economic context that we're suffering of a worldwide crisis, our industrial model has shown its robustness and for several reasons. First of all, electricity is a vital commodity with utilizations that will continue to grow throughout the world. The high demand continues to withstand well, in spite of this context of economic recession and we are convinced based on what we we've observed is that electricity out of all the energies is what is growing the fastest everywhere. Indeed, while our efforts to -- for demand managements do continue to reduce the consumption per use, the number of uses of electricities have been multiplying.

In practical terms, what we are observing today is that our large industrial accounts are obviously impacted by the economic context, but we are also seeing, particularly in France, that there is a growth in residential consumption, particularly via growing uses that will offset the decline of industrial consumption. Beyond this, the key energy issues of security of supply and the fight against climate warming fits within a timeline that goes well beyond the timeline of this crisis.

Neglecting to respond to this dual energy and environmental challenge today, particularly if you are a global nuclear leader with 36 million customers in Europe, that would severely jeopardize our industrial future, the future of our whole industry and the future of the economic developments. In order to respond to these issues, we need to invest as of today in energy savings, renewable energy sources and nuclear power. And this is precisely what is at stake when we relaunched the CapEx program back in 2005.

Last year, EDF Group invested nearly 30% more in capital expenditure in order to maintain and expand our generation facilities and improve the quality of high transmission and distribution grids. 2009 we will be speeding up the pace of these efforts, particularly in France where we'll be investing over €8 billion, thereby contributing to create approximately 20,000 direct or in-direct jobs in France.

In order to finance these investments, we can rely on the soundness of our balance sheet on the recurrence of our revenues and on our excellent financial rating, which is the best in the industry. Daniel Camus will tell you more about that later. We enjoy one of the most outstanding corporate signature in the market as attested by the success of our recent transaction on the bond market, where we were able to raise nearly €8 billion in January alone.

Last but not least, let me emphasize that the competitiveness of nuclear power has been boosted versus the analysis we had some -- a few years ago. Indeed, beyond the lower commodity prices due to the economic context and oil in particular, it is obvious that ultimately the growing scarcity of hydrocarbons will necessarily lead to a sustained high level of the oil barrel and the extensive independence of our generation assets versus hydrocarbons, hydropower and nuclear guarantees the profitability over the long-term.

The construction of new EPR reactors with a 60-year planned life span fits within this long-term vision. A few weeks ago, we reevaluated the cost of the EPR Flamanville by 20%. Back in 2005, this cost was estimated at €3.3 billion, it is now estimated at €4 billion for 2008. In the mean time, the cost of a gas-fired plant concurrently increased 45%, so up 20% for a nuclear plant and while the cost for a coal-fired plant went up 54%. Hence, we boosted the competitiveness of the nuclear power over this period. These results should be assessed in the context of a difficult economic environment that has impacted many industries. In this context, we nevertheless were able to keep and preserve our results.

Sales revenue consolidated that reached €64.3 billion and organic growth of 10.6%. EBITDA that stood at €15.4 billion before the, of course, of the extended TaRTAM transition tariff. But excluding this non recurring item, the EBITDA has enjoyed an organic growth of 3.7%. After restatement of the TaRTAM linked provision of 1.2 billion, this leads to an EBITDA of €14.2 billion. Net income from ordinary operations stood at €4.3 billion, slightly down 6.4% in terms of organic growth.

In France as I said earlier, our financial results were significantly penalized by a provision that was allowed in 2008; i.e., €1.2 billion which is linked to the one year extension of the TaRTAM transition tariff until mid 2010. Hence, the EBITDA is down nearly 10%. Excluding this impact, EBITDA would have been up over 2%. Over the concerned period for the TaRTAM, that is between early 2007 and mid 2010, the cumulative compensation that we had and will have to pay to our competitors reached or will reach approximately €2 billion. Internationally and this is cause for great satisfaction for 2008, all of our international subsidiaries have been profitable and have been driving up the growth of the Group. International revenue was up over 15% in organic growth and EBITDA was up 6.5%.

2008, let me emphasize this, was a key milestone for the industrial future of our Group. We've made significant progress in implementing our long-term strategy. We have reasserted our leadership in nuclear revival throughout the world. We've boosted our industrial positions and footprints in Europe and we have promoted renewable energy sources as well as energy efficiency. Let's take a look at these three points one-by-one.

Leadership in nuclear revival. Our progress in this nuclear power revival throughout the world relies first and foremost and that gives us – makes us a step ahead. It relies as I said, on the exemplary supervision of the construction of the EPR in Flamanville. In spite of technical contingencies which of course are inherent to construction of such scope and perplexity, we had – we used the necessary resources to keep the construction schedule under control and we confirmed the target for commissioning in 2012. And we were very pleased in fact by the approval by French Public Authorities of our project to build a second EPR in France at the Penly site.

The EPR technology, of course, is a tremendous showcase for French technology and constitutes the best passport for EDF's international expansion in nuclear power. Hence, this is excellent news for EDF, excellent news for the entire nuclear industry. It's also excellent news for the energy independence of France and its commercial trade balance. EDF as I said and I confirm is open to well balanced partnership to be signed with other energy operators such as Enel, which is already our partner at Flamanville or GDF Suez, as well as any other European operators.

We will be continuing to investigate these key industrial projects in our various governance bodies and in full compliance with all consultation procedures. In this context, we are planning to start construction in 2012; i.e., the very year when the Flamanville EPR would be -- will be commissioned. Based on this calendar, we will be able to rely on the expertise and skills of the crews that are currently building the EPR in the Mosh area.

Internationally, we have gained durable positions in the three key markets for nuclear development over the next 10 years. If you take the three main nuclear markets, we have -- we are present in China, in the U.K. and in the USA. In China, of course, the energy market that is growing fastest in the world, we have already started the construction of two EPR reactors at Taishan site in the context of a joint venture in which we hold 30% stake together with historical partner in China CGNPC.

In the United Kingdom, we believe that the British market will be the European market that will grow the fastest in the nuclear sector. The acquisition of British Energy bolsters our -- the economic and industrial model of EDF Energy. Our British subsidiaries, thanks to a major increase of our power generation capacities, basically multiplied by three, that will enable us to cover the needs of our customers. And also thanks to a boosted non-CO2 free power generation, that will be reaching 58% of the total generation. Hence, we've already acquired a major and solid footprints in the U.K. and we will further strengthen it tomorrow by building and operating at least four new EPR reactors in the future.

As you know, we've also initiated discussions with the British company Centrica to look at conditions for its partnership in this operation up to 25% stake that would be acquired under the same conditions as our own acquisitions. Today, we are quite confident that agreements can be signed with Centrica over the next few weeks and in any case before the end of the first quarter 2009.

Third key market for nuclear expansion is the United States, which is of course the largest global energy market. In the U.S., we made an offering to acquire 50% of the nuclear assets of our partner in the U.S., Constellation, and we intend to build four EPR reactors, the first of which are at the site of Calvert Cliffs in the state of Maryland.

Getting back to Europe now, we've been consolidating our industrial positions, as I said in the U.K., where we've become a leader in the power market in the U.K. In Germany, our subsidiary EnBV (sic) [EnBW] , announced an acquisition of a 26% stake in the EVE Municipal Utility company for €2 billion. EnBV (sic) [EnBW] has also announced the acquisition of 520 megawatts in fossil-fire generations from E.ON. In Switzerland, EDF with its 25% stake in the capital of ALPIQ, EDF has become the international and industrial benchmark partner of the new energy leader in the country, now named ALPIQ, which is actually a combination of the business activities of Atel and EOS, both Swiss energy operators.

Lastly in the natural gas, Edison has boosted its position as well. In particular, with access to new gas reserves in Egypt and with the commissioning plan this year of the very first offshore LNG terminal built in Rovigo. Lastly, EDF has gained a majority stake in gas fields in the North Sea, all of which contributes to strengthen supply – security of supply for gas for the entire Group.

The energy efficiency and sustainable development component includes naturally renewable energy sources where we've speeded up the pace of expansion by defining new growth targets for our subsidiary EDF Energy Nouvelles. These targets now involve 4,000 megawatts of installed capacities by 2012, including 500 megawatt in the form of solar photovoltaic power. In order to support this ambition, we were involved in the capital increase of 500 million that took place last year at EDF Energy in Nouvelles.

In hydropower, which is the leading renewable energy, we have continued our SuperHydro maintenance program for which we had announced an investment of €500 million over five years and in 2008 naturally we completed – we made major progress at the Nam Theun dam construction site in Laos. We recently completed the filling of the reservoir dam.

From the commercial standpoint, we continue and we will continue the roll out of our energy efficiency offerings. Hence, 250,000 services offers for energy services and renewable energy, particularly decentralized energy in France were rolled out. Lastly, we've announced our choice of a technology to build the very first marine current turbine at the Paimpol-Brehat site in Brittany in the context of our pilot trial to build current turbine to produce electricity from the energy contained in tidal currents.
This is it for my introduction. Daniel Camus will now detail the financial results from the year. Daniel Camus, you have the floor, sir.

Good morning to all. Just a few details about the Group's income statement in France and abroad. Regarding the overall figures, two comments I'd like to make. First, we're on target given what we said regarding EBITDA. Outside -- excluding the impact of TaRTAM, we had said that we would be around 3%; we're 3.7% today. With significant TaRTAM impact slightly higher than planned, a net income minus 4%, it's at minus 6% at the end of the year, very much impacted by the resumption of investments, which I will tell you more about it in a moment.

Today, we are in a situation regarding organic growth, sales in EBITDA. Regarding the scope, the most important thing is Mexico having an impact – a reduction of 650 million from one year to the other, 110 million for EBITDA. Regarding exchange, the only significant impact is related to the British pound. You know how the pound has evolved, that has had a negative impact of 1.2 billion on sales, a little less than 200 million on EBITDA. So the figure being 10.6, 3.7 with major difference between France and International. In France plus 2.2%, at the International level we have a rate of plus 6.5%.

One word about the TaRTAM. It makes a difference whether you look at the figures with or without the TaRTAM, the figures are quite different, the amount is very high. We -- for the enabling legislation, we had made a preliminary estimation of a billion, where the actual figure is 1.2 billion. The few parameters used are the following: this is the setting up of a provision related to the fact that TaRTAM was extended for a year. Second half of '09, first half of 2010 on a volume of close to 40 additional terawatt hour, an average sourcing cost of competitors calculated around €68, around €43, 32 times the volume gives a figure of €1.2 billion and rounded figure, a very substantial figure without absorption, no financing capacity available from CSPA after tax, 783 million after-tax as Pierre was saying. Between '06, '07, '09, that represents €2 billion. 1.2 billion plus 800 million that is for the TaRTAM impact.

As for the overall income statement globally and then per country, you see that fuel and energy purchases have gone up by 3.8 billion, more than 20% from one fiscal period to the other, especially Internationally. Here you have the gas, the formal gas and coal impact and in France you have figure of 18%. As for the OpEx, a total of one plus 5% over the period, more strongly in France 7%, 1.4% internationally. I'll give you more information about the France aspect in a minute.

We'll start with by France. In France, the first graph now that you probably know in parallel the variation in production and purchases sales. First thing, despite kD that is lower than last years', 79.2%, thanks to a usage rate that is better than last year. Last year it was 94.2%, this year it's 95.2, so generation is almost stable 0.4 of variation.

The usage rate has almost made up for the KD that is lower than last year's, one point. Hydraulic, hydropower plus 4.8% which is under seasonal averages, but better than the last two fiscal periods. Generation explains almost all of the totality 4.8, 4.9. On the right hand side, the distribution of sales, an increasing amount of sales to end-users. Out of the 441 million, about 300 terawatt hours or at tariff in one form or the other 300 out of 441, 55 TaRTAM. As for net wholesale markets and auctions, they go down by 12 terawatt hour. So a kind of a shear effect, one interacting with the other favorable on VPP, plus three terawatt hour, minus 54 net wholesale markets and auctions.

I'd like to dwell a little on France, most of what I said is related to France. The sales growth broken down into three parts. First part, the volume effect, in total 1.5% increase out of 6.3% networks, the volume energy component's 1.3 billion, and net market sales, the reflection -- the translation in euro from the previous graph, total of 1.5%. Prices and tariffs -- that represents an evolution of 3.8%. In this amount, the price increase represents 600 million out of the 1.245 billion and price forward VPP 410 million. Natural Gas and Services, it's a small amount, out of the 336 million gas sales represent 208, 3.7% of market sales for end-users. So much for sales.

As for the rest of the income statement, 1.4 billion in absolute values with a cost of 1.6 billion and also a cost of fuel -- 100 in fossil fuel – 140 million and those purchases. Another important change, the evolution of OpEx. The totals of staff cost and other external consumption increases by 7% in total, of which 6% for personal staff, 8% for other external consumption.

I'd like to remind you what we said at the beginning of the year about the step effect that did a number of costs that are going to become structural, that is related to retirement. If you make them about retirement 150 million nuclear, maintenance and other expenses, representing 300 million plus 50 million total. Out of this 7%, 500 million; i.e., 4% contribute to what we said the increase the base cost, which doesn't change the natural evolution of cost. The major – the two major changes you see in France that there is a significant volume effect, but also a kD usage rate impact plus a high OpEx impact plus 7%.

At the International level, as Pierre said earlier, a good performance at the International level almost everywhere throughout the world. I'd even say everywhere, with a higher contribution of trading given the volatility of markets, this year was the best for EDF Trading -- plus 6.5% for EBITDA. If you restate for the effect of IAS 39 regarding a number of contracts, this increase would have been 21% at the International level. If we didn't take into account the effect of IAS 39, this was therefore an excellent year.

The major figures EDF Energy for the subsidiary this is what you have the most significant effect of IAS 39 and sometime asked this question in England in '06. The effect was negative and also in total you have an impact of 438 million over this period. If you have any questions resulting from the valuation of hedging commodity contract, a negative effect outside of that you see that the operating basis of EDF Energy is sound and has grown by 23%. Thanks notably to significant tariff increases last year, EDF Energy has raised the tariff of 25% for power and 35% for gases, the situation being the reverse this year. There is also the effect of grid revaluation.

One word about British Energy. Clearly, British Energy is only partly in the accounts, given it was only acquired '09, but it will enter the Company's consolidation scope as of January 1. We have finished the deal from a financial point of view since January 9, so we have consolidated a full-year of British Energy in our accounts.

One important thing, the acquisition cost of British Energy is 13.5 billion. You'll remember from our previous presentations that we had estimated the maximum amount to 15.7 billion. So there is a two billion difference related to the parity between the Euro and the Pound which wasn't at all favorable to us. Same thing for consolidation, in Euros there is difference of two billion related. The consolidation will be done by global integration with 25% of minority interest.

Centrica we're waiting for the conclusion of agreements for the end of the first quarter. Everything is going according to plan, even though there are few difficulties, but things are going well with Centrica.

In the disposal mentioned by Mr. Gadonneix the 25% are not mentioned, this is on top and not included in the €5 billion of disposal present. This is on top of the €5 billion. I heard some people asking the question. As for the contribution to Group EBITDA, it would be around €1.5 billion with an impact in the first year for the part that is not covered by the portfolio, the price reduction in U.K., so we're exposed on that part. We will be presenting end of June the allocation of the acquisition cost; the purchase accounting will be finalized at this date.

A few words about E&BV (sic) [EnBW] . You know that they published their figures two days ago. The figures are excellent, mainly thanks to the electrical activities of the group plus 13% sales wholesale optimization of the upstream portfolio, all of the purchase were favorable. Unfortunately, you know that the German regulators reviewed the tariff of the gas sector which has an impact of 174 million in our accounts impairment. And we should have a number of information from German competition soon.

Italy. The beginning of the year was difficult for Edison. I don't know if you remember, we were at minus 25% of EBITDA – for EBITDA the first quarter, which is very -- was very bad. Our ambition was at least duplicate last year's performance which was good in the end, plus 5% for EBITDA in Italy, with a very positive price effect. Arbitrage tradeoff between end-user not so much for . Globally, plus 5%. Here again you have seen that Edison just published their accounts for 2009. They would like replicate at least, despite price volume volatility and the way they would like to have the replicate the same performance in '09.

What about the rest of Europe? This is EBITDA of 2.2 billion. It's -- more than the rest of Europe, it's more than Germany, more than Italy combined. It's very productive for the Group, which changes very quickly plus 22%. All segments are progressing. EDF Trading has had a historic year plus 78%, 1.24 billion of contribution to EBITDA. Trading margins have gone up by more than 90%. As for gas, they have gone up of more than 50%. The year was very good. EDF Energy Nouvelles has just also had an increase in EBITDA plus 33%. Eastern Europe same thing increase rates of eight to 10%. Hungary, for example, with double-digit growth rate. A good year for the rest of Europe and all European countries, outside of the impact of IAS 39, EBITDA plus 20%.

Operating excellence, thanks to our sales on markets and thanks to our second performance program launched at the end of the first quarter of 2008. We're almost on target 285 million. We have low startup, but now we have more than 300 identified projects. You see the distribution between France and abroad one-third, two-thirds. Clearly, we're on target and they're going to be increasingly delivering to reach an objective of 600 million, one billion also. This is an excellent guarantee for the company.

One word about the change in net income. I have seen regarding the consensus, I was able to see that the financial results was one of sources of variance. I'd like to tell you about the move. There's a mechanical move which might not be perceived by all, an impact of – negative impact of 600 million on financial result the difference between two years -- 633 million. A minor impact related to the increase in the cost of that 52 million, which is not much when you see the increase of debt. A lot of outlays are done at the end of the year. So, only an impact of 50 million, but a more important impact related to the increase in discounting expenditures, an increase in discounting expenditure related to the enlargement of nuclear provision -- the increase of the base of nuclear provision. So the discounting base increases by 165 million. That is a source of variance from an arithmetic point of view.

Third factor, 400 million related to the drop in financial expenditures and income. We have carried out in '08 an impairment of our shares in Constellation. Based on the intrinsic value, an impairment of €156 million.

Another element related to corporate income tax, it's higher by 33% whereas it was 24.5% last year. This is a mechanical factor again last year Germany, U.K. and Italy had announced a reform in corporate income tax. We had to in fact a free number of deferred assets. This is not the case here and this is the main reason explaining why this year we had a higher rate of 33% instead of 31, 32%.

I'd like to tell you now about non-recurring elements. Last year we had number of positive element with important contribution. Capital gains disposal – capital gains on disposal, Mexico notably this year, you see that out of the minus 908 million, there's one that weighs more than the others. What I said earlier, 783 million because of TaRTAM law. It's very high, then 246 for the E&BV (sic) [EnBW] Grid Gas provision for risks impairment and also the impairment on Constellation of 156 million.

Dividend as announced in spite of lower recurring income, a constant dividend that will remain constant between '07 and '08 of €1.28 per share. We paid in interim dividend in December of 0.64; the balance will be paid; i.e., €0.64 per share.

Few words about the cash flow. We see the FFO funds from operation of 10.1 billion, with two significant cash consumption sources. The first one is, naturally, capital expenditure for 9.7 billion, below the average of 12 billion for the next three years, yes definitely. But a sharp increase of 30% versus the previous fiscal year.

Working capital variation 2.5 billion due to several factors. Increased inventories 800 million; that is coal, gas, oil, fuel oil and so on all combined, all of which are impacted. And an increase of margin calls that are linked to the upstream, downstream optimization and trading activities of approximately €700 million. The remainder €800 million, the receivables of course increase, the tradables increase and so on. So, cash consumption of 2.5 billion largely temporary and that will be reversed naturally over the coming months.

Net debt as of end December 2008, we went from 16.3 up to 24.5 billion, with dedicated assets of 1.8 billion below the normal practice, since in view of the extreme volatility, we suspended these allowance allocation for dedicated assets. When you have a volatility of 70% on your stock while historically it was down at 20, clearly that would be an investment in view of our 20-30, 20-35 timeline would not be advisable. So 1.8% -- 1.8 billion in dedicated assets.

Acquisitions, out of the 4.6 you have two cash payments. British Energy 2.7, approximately 26% shares bought from the market for a total amount of 2.7 billion, purchased in 2008. That's for British Energy and 1.3 billion for Constellation. We had interest payment of one billion on the 17th of December to be reimbursed, if you will, offset at the time of closing. So British Energy, Constellation that's four billion out of these 4.6 billion in acquisition. If you want details on the remaining acquisitions, let me know. This was an overview of EDF Energy's net debt.

In conclusion, a few words. In the current context, it's important to take a look at the financial position of the company, which is very sound. EDF, of course, has been managing its financial position in a very cautious and serene manner. Our debt of 24 billion is a multiple of 1.7 EBITDA. You can access that versus the industry average. That should be increasing in 2009 naturally, with a payment to be made on Constellation and British Energy.

Cash-flow from operations, FFO that always exceeds €10 billion in a recurring manner. Access to bank facilities and credits are I would call them preferred. We were able to mobilize €11 billion to finance the British Energy transaction while no other company anywhere can raise 11 billion on syndicated loan markets. We've already paid back 50% in advance out of these 11 credit facility, which was on the 5th of January. Now we're down at 5.5 billion. We have two years normally to reimburse it, one year plus one year renewable. The very first tranche of that credit facility was fully pre-paid, the rest of course has a longer maturity date. We had several – we had several bond issues and a 7% average cost is actually been reduced in all of these bond issues.

Second pillar €10 billion in available syndicated undrawn credit lines, including six billion in France, 3.8 of course for EnDW and Edison, with a reserve just in case, no intention for the time being to draw on it, but it is a good financial cushion if you will.

And on the right hand side as you see here, this is situation of financial markets which can be absolutely crazy sometime these days, but EDF's corporate name is doing well and is well accepted in the financial markets. We've been issuing annual securities, our treasury bonds in the U.S. and various bonds in reoccurring way. In Europe, we now reached 5.5 billion. And we're one of these industrial players that fuel and feed from these financial markets in a regular manner.

And as Pierre Gadonneix said earlier, we proved able to finalize several -- two major bond issues for the past few months. We issued over €11 billion since the end of November, with the first wave of 3.5-4 billion in November, December. Then we issued two billion in Euros and that was the biggest operation, plus ₣1.4 billion and 400 million in Sterlings, with two issues of two times two billion in Euros once again. And for the first time ever in 20 years, we went back to the U.S bond market and we found a demand that exceeded the offer. We raised five billion in the U.S. on five,10 and 30 years maturity date. The lowest rate for the ₤6 bond at 5.1%, the highest rate is the $30 bond at 6.9% just to give you an idea of the rates.

So, we've extended the maturity of the corporate debt and we lowered the financial cost. So, today very early in this year we have financed most of our requirements. The majority of our bond requirements at a cost, if you look at the dollar between the time three weeks ago when we issued and today, we would have been paying 100 basis points in addition, quite simply because Governments of all countries of course are now very active on these bond markets. So, just to tell you of course there are investing problems. We're currently -- we will be finalizing the acquisitions of British Energy and of Constellation, but we already – we already have behind us most of the – all of the financing conditions at preferred conditions, particularly in view of the current markets. Thank you.

Thank you, Daniel. Before opening up the Q&A session, let me say a few words to shed some light on the future and for these results in perspective of the current context in which we operate. First of all, in an industry like ours it's always essential to remember the major changes in the regulatory context. Let me start with a few details, some insight of what's happening in this area.

In France to begin with, last November the French government created a new Commission chaired by Mr. Champsaur, the so called Champsaur Commission, to identify future potential changes in tariffs and rates particularly in view of TaRTAM maturity. The deadline is 2010 for these transition tariffs and it is viewed well is the context of opening competition on deregulated markets in view as well changes in European directives. The EU commission is expected to release its proposals in March or April.

Brief reminder as well about changes in European regulation. The adoption of the climate package last December is a major indicator of the future context over the coming years. Indeed, this climate package increases the competitiveness of carbon free or low carbon energy in view of course of the challenge of this directive on CO2 cost. Hence, this will boost once again the competitiveness of nuclear power.

In addition, the European Commission last December notified a list of grievances to EDF linked to the long-term purchasing in commercial contracts with our industrial customers. The Commission is worried about the compatibility between relationships with industrial customers and the competition rules on an EU level. And EDF is currently preparing responses to start discussions with the EU Commissions.

In the U.S., we're now expecting guidelines from the new administration, though first indications seem to show that the new U.S. Administration is in favor of lower carbon economy. Lastly, in 2009 the Copenhagen conference will be held, a location for all countries in the world to agree on the continuation or renewal of the Kyoto protocol that is planned to run until 2012, a protocol that defines the context for sustainable development.

All of this confirms that energy independence and the fight against climate warming are the two key long-term challenges for the energy industry and both are at the height of EDF's strategy. Another point I would like to stress for -- in the context of our business for the coming years in particularly for 2009. Let me add that for EDF the year 2006 included highly structuring operations of acquisitions. I spoke about them earlier, so did Daniel Camus. 2009, in turn, will be devoted to organic growth and to the integration of our acquisitions.

After laying the foundations of our industrial growth and expansion, we now need to guarantee the conditions of its success and this will involve a number of projects, topics, issues. I would like to mention in particular the improvement of our nuclear efficiency performance. We confirm our target to increase the availability factor of our French nuclear plants from 79.2% Kd in 2008 up to 85% by 2011; i.e., a pace of improvement that is close to 2% per annum in terms of Kd availability factor. To do so, we will be taking measures at different levels, all of which are currently underway and have already started.

The first level will be to speed up the heavy maintenance investments, which have doubled between 2005 and 2008 and that is designed in particular to improve the availability factor -- Kd factor. Second area of improvement will be to reduce the duration of maintenance shutdowns by improving the organization of operations. Third area of improvement will be to extend the life span or the life cycle of fuel recharge for four of our nuclear units. Fourthly, we want to continue to deal with the technical failures and contingency that we mentioned earlier, namely on steam generators and alternators.

And now another way to improve the efficiency of our power assets is the potential extension of the life span of our nuclear assets, which is of course a key driver. I remind you that reactors of similar technologies that are currently operate in the U.S. -- several dozens of them -- have now been authorized to operate for a life span of 60 years. Hence, we will be opening discussions with the nuclear safety authorities in the context of the preparation of the next 10-year shutdown inspections, or rather maintenance inspections in the French power plants. Just to give you an idea and an order of magnitude, we estimate that investments required to extend the life span of a reactor by 20 years to approximately 10% of the cost of a new built EPR type power plant. Hence, this as I repeat, this is a tremendous driver, but will require additional investment efforts over the coming years.

Year 2009 will also involve a continuation of our operational capital spending in our industrial assets in order to boost its efficiency and performance and to continue to respond to requirements of service quality and service level. We'll be investing this year over eight billion, you see here on this slide 7.5, because this is a proportion of EDF SA. To recheck, when I speak up €8 billion we naturally include our French subsidiaries in particularly – in particular EDF Energy Nouvelles in the renewable sector. So, we will be investing over €8 billion in France; i.e., €2.5 billion more than in 2008. These investments are of course necessary. Recent incidents have reminded us of this necessity.

I remind you that the lower power exports from France in 2008 shows that we no longer have any surplus capacities. Of course, we've been anticipating all this since 2005, and since then we've already commissioned over 3,000-megawatt of essentially fossil-fire capacities between 2006 and '08. The target at the time was to commission 6,000-megawatts in addition by 2012, so we've now reached halfway. These 3000 megawatts in newly available capacities have enabled us to face the cold spell in early January. For three days in a row, where we had record peak demand, we made good use of these new capacities. Hence, these investment efforts must continue over time.

And so, we have a number of projects underway and particularly the gas fired plants in Blenod and Martigues this will be CCGT plants, the EPR in Flamanville of course is an ongoing project and the second EPR reactor to be built in Penly, all of which goes in the same direction, meaning that we've now come back to a sustainable pace for the development of new capacities.

In the field of networks, grids, weather supply or transmission grids, maintaining the quality of our public service will require new capital spending as well. Investments that are to be incorporated in the ongoing discussions on the third party access rates. The recent weather conditions of course have emphasized the importance of this challenge. You see EDF has stayed the course of investment, has pursued its industrial project to secure the growth of tomorrow.

In order to funding this capital spending, what are we going to do? Well, first of all and as always, we will be counting on ourselves. As I told you last year and Daniel Camus referred it to it earlier, we launched last year a program to improve our performance, which we call Operational Excellence program, intended to improve our income and profits by optimizing our operational processes. This program is now underway, and will continue for three years. It's applicable to France as well as foreign subsidiaries. And the first results obtained in 2008 are in line with our expectations. We are thereby confirming our target of €1 billion in net synergy gains on EBITDA by 2010. And of course we have regular exchanges with public authorities regarding the level of prices, rates and tariffs that are necessary to back and support the resumption of investments both in generation assets as well as transmission or distribution grids.

Year 2009 will also be a year for us to integrate our newly acquired companies. Our targets were synergy gains, which we had estimated at the time of British Energy acquisition, namely €220 million per annum starting from the 3rd year of integration. And it's a new organization of our business in the U.K., which is currently going on and partially implemented is designed precisely to reach these performance gains. We've already found that the four – we've already re-commissioned or restarted four reactors that had been shut down for several months in Hartlepool and Heysham and we're quite confident that all four reactors will be fully operational before the end of this month.

Lastly, EDF is particularly pleased with the progress recently announced and the changes recently announced by the British Public Authorities regarding the certification and consulting procedures for the commissioning of a new EPR type nuclear power plant by 2017.

After having recalled this context in this main orientation, 2001 (sic) [2011] will be a year in which we will continue and consolidate the actions started in '08 with the priority to internal growth and the integration of acquired companies. And of course, the financial and economic crisis, which is unprecedented at the world level, will necessarily mark this year in 2009 and our group might feel the impact of the crisis. But our conviction is that this impact will be more limited than in other sectors.

This impact will depend on the countries and on the activities of the group, depending on their sensitivity to price changes for electricity -- consumption of electricity. In France for example, we are very little exposed to market prices because of our generation mix. 90% of our generation is nuclear and or hydraulic is not impacted by changes in energy prices, notably oil prices. And also because of the fact that our prices – the prices at which we sell electricity are tariff prices, hence non-sensitive to the uncertainties of market prices.

As out of France, however, subsidiaries will have to take account of the new situation. They have hedging policies as normal in this sector. These hedging policies can change from one country to another, therefore the market price exposure might vary from one subsidiary to another. Given all that, we are confident for 2009.

At the financial level now, we are anticipating enhanced and faster growth of EBITDA because of the acquisitions made in 2008 and their integration. On a like-for-like basis -- on the basis of the same scope, our organic growth objective for EBITDA is modest given the economic context I have just recalled.

The net income excluding non-recurring elements should not be growing, especially since we are going to be continuing our investment program. We will have a growth of EBITDA, but not the net income. We are taking all necessary measures to face the present economic situation and as I said, our ambition is to improve our operating performance. In parallel, we have decided to start a disposal program, the objective of which being as when we did for 2006, 2009, our objective here would be to reduce the debt by at least €5 billion between 2009 and 2010. This is why we are starting 2009 with confidence.

We want to keep our industrial ambition and of course this goes much beyond the time horizon of the crisis. I would like to tell you again how much trust I have in EDF's industrial future. This company is just being recognized as being the preferred company of the French population. 2008 will certainly have -- meant a change in our industrial ambition. We have laid the foundation of a sustainable growth.

The future of the EDF Group is now part and parcel of Europe and more broadly in the world wherever nuclear revival has started. This is a formidable opportunity for our group, for its employees, its customers, its partners, and its shareholders. Thank you very much for your attention.
